page.title: 12SPAINS HALL ARCHITECTURE.
page.content: Architecturally Spains Hall is Elizabethan in style.It is built of red brick with clustered chimneys, curvilinear gables,mullioned and transomed windows and is irregular in plan.It is typical of the great Essex manor houses in the older tradition with central hall,porch and cross-wings.Since it was built in the late sixteenth century it was altered in 1637 and partially rebuilt in 1768, but it retains its Tudor character. Internally there is an elegant dining room,hall,panelled library and a charming drawing room.The Tapestry Room is of special interest as are the domestic quarters which include a gun room,boot and lamp rooms and kitchen. The grounds have pleasant gardens and a Prayer House,rebuilt in 1839 at the end of the Elizabethan wall.
